explanation.text: The claim states that increasing c-axis spacing stabilizes Cu-O octahedral coordination in La₂CuO₄. CHGNet MLIP calculations reveal a non-monotonic energy trend: small expansion (+2%) shows slight stabilization of -0.061 eV/atom, exceeding the significance threshold of 0.01 eV/atom. However, larger expansions (+5% and +10%) cause progressive destabilization, with the +10% case showing +1.08 eV/atom energy increase relative to baseline.

Structural analysis reveals that Cu-O octahedral coordination is not preserved across the tested c-axis range. Apical Cu-O bond lengths exceed 3.8 Å at all tested values (baseline, +2%, +5%, +10%), indicating broken or severely weakened apical coordination. Normal octahedral apical Cu-O bonds are approximately 2.4 Å. Equatorial Cu-O bonds range from 2.1-2.9 Å, showing distortion from ideal octahedral geometry.

Literature on Jahn-Teller distortions in Cu(II) d⁹ octahedral complexes confirms that moderate c-axis elongation can be energetically favorable due to eg orbital splitting. Axial Cu-O bonds are typically ~17% longer than equatorial bonds in such systems. However, excessive elongation breaks octahedral coordination, consistent with the observed CHGNet behavior at larger c-axis expansions.

The claim's universal wording implies monotonic stabilization with increasing c-axis spacing, which is contradicted by the computational evidence. Stabilization occurs only in a narrow window (~+2% expansion), beyond which the structure destabilizes significantly. The loss of octahedral coordination across all tested values further undermines the claim that this geometry is 'stabilized' by c-axis expansion.

The Likert score of -1 (Partially Infeasible) reflects that while the claim captures a real physical effect (Jahn-Teller stabilization at small distortions), it overgeneralizes this effect beyond its valid range. The claim would be accurate if qualified to 'small' or 'moderate' c-axis increases, but as stated universally, it is contradicted by destabilization at larger expansions and structural degradation.

chgnet_obs_0.citation: Energy per atom: -6.6184 eV (1.02× c); -5.5982 eV (1.10× c). Cu-O bond lengths: equatorial 2.1-2.9 Å; apical > 3.8 Å. Maximum forces: 0.005 eV/Å (1.02× c); 0.134 eV/Å (1.10× c). Small stabilization (ΔE ≈ -0.061 eV) at +2% c; strong destabilization at +5% and +10% c.

energy_trend.citation: Non-monotonic energy trend: +2% expansion shows -0.061 eV/atom stabilization; +5% and +10% expansions show progressive destabilization up to +1.08 eV/atom relative to baseline.

structural_analysis.citation: Cu-O octahedra not preserved at any c-scale; apical Cu-O distances > 3.8 Å indicate broken apical bonds (normal octahedral apical bonds ~2.4 Å). Equatorial bonds 2.1-2.9 Å show distortion.

search_obs_1_source_0.citation: The Jahn–Teller effect is most often encountered in octahedral complexes, especially six-coordinate copper(II) complexes. The d9 electronic configuration of this ion gives three electrons in the two degenerate eg orbitals, leading to a doubly degenerate electronic ground state. Such complexes distort along one of the molecular fourfold axes (always labelled the z axis), which has the effect of removing the orbital and electronic degeneracies and lowering the overall energy. The distortion normally takes the form of elongating the bonds to the ligands lying along the z axis

search_obs_1_source_1.citation: In contrast, it turns out that the two axial Cu-O distances are 17% longer than the two equatorial Cu-O distances. In the case of Cu(II), which is d9, there are two electrons in one eg orbital and one in the other. If one of the orbitals goes down in energy and the other goes up, there may be no overall change in the energy of the orbitals, but there is a net decrease in electronic energy because two electrons are going down while only one is going up

jahn_teller_context.citation: Jahn-Teller distortion in Cu(II) d⁹ octahedral complexes naturally causes c-axis elongation with axial bonds ~17% longer than equatorial. Moderate distortion is stabilizing due to eg orbital splitting, but excessive elongation breaks octahedral coordination.

synthesis.source: Integration of computational and literature evidence
synthesis.citation: The claim overgeneralizes a limited physical effect. Small c-axis expansion (+2%) shows stabilization consistent with Jahn-Teller physics, but larger expansions destabilize the structure and degrade octahedral coordination. The universal wording of the claim is contradicted by the non-monotonic energy trend and structural degradation.
